Hello Ian,

Thanks yes I browsed through those threads. I am most intereste=
d in 
optimizing the sigmoid for now. I have implemented many of the other =

great optimizations mentioned. I saw the other sigmoid approximations 
and=
 some of them were quite fast but this speed was offset by poor 
learning c=
haracteristics of the resulting programs. 

I ran my code with the standard=
 sigmoid for a given number of 
generations and kept track of the random se=
ed, the final fitness and 
the run time. I replaced the standard sigmoid wi=
th an approximated 
sigmoid. Then I evolved a net using the same seed and m=
easured how 
long it took to arrive at the same fitness as the net with the=
 
standard sigmoid ( although when the approximated sigmoids when run 
in i=
solation they were much faster than the standard sigmoid). When 
trying to =
evolve a net with the same level of fitness in a given 
amount of time they=
 actually negatively impacted performance! I think 
this is a more accurate=
 way to measure real performance of the 
application. I think it doesn't re=
ally matter how fast the parts of 
the program run but how fast the program=
 completes the task it was 
created for.

Because of the problems I saw wit=
h the other approximations I decided 
to try and create my own sigmoid appr=
oximation with good learning 
characteristics and a fast runtime. To do thi=
s I created an 
approximation that closely follows the curve of the origina=
l sigmoid 
and that is relatively smooth and continuous. I think the reason=
 why 
the other sigmoid approximations has such poor learning 
characterist=
ics is because they were either to simple, or not smooth. 
I think if they =
are too simple you can't combine them in very may 
ways to arrive at a good=
 approximation of a given function. This is 
why a straight line or a stepp=
ed function generally makes a poor 
activation function. If they aren't con=
tinuous small changes in the 
weights can cause big jumps or erratic jumps.=
 Which can make it hard 
to converge on an optimal solution.

I have only r=
un my sigmoid approx on the problems I am interested in 
so my high regard =
for it is probably unfounded and naive. But it 
definitely seems to improve=
 the rate of learning for the problems I 
am interested in right now.

My n=
ext major optimization project is going to be implementing a 
GPGPU ANN imp=
lementation. I am hopefully hiring a chap in a few days 
to work on this pr=
oject. It will be exciting to see if I can get the 
same performance gains =
(30 fold) from the GPGPU as others have in the 
papers I have read. Anyone =
have any experience with this?

Wow I wrote way to much. Sorry guys!

Thank=
s,

Shane
